message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with weakness in abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination of the left arm, which suggests damage to the C5-C6 nerve roots, as these roots innervate the muscles responsible for these movements. The radial nerve innervates the triceps brachii, forearm extensors, and wrist extensors, which are not affected in this patient. The C8-T1 nerve roots innervate the hand and fingers, which the patient denies having any sensory changes in, and the long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is not implicated in the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weakness in abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination of the left arm suggest that C5 and C6 nerve roots are likely damaged, as these nerve roots innervate the muscles responsible for these movements. The location of the injury, left shoulder region with moderate bruising, does not suggest damage to the radial nerve or long thoracic nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms indicate a brachial plexus injury, which commonly involves the C5-C6 nerve roots. The lack of sensory changes and normal radiograph suggest that bones and nerves are not damaged. The radial nerve innervates extensor muscles of the arm and hand, and the long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is not mentioned in the symptom description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has weakness in abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination, which are all controlled by the C5-C6 nerve roots. C8-T1 nerve roots control intrinsic hand muscles, radial nerve controls wrist extensors, and long thoracic nerve controls serratus anterior muscle, none of which match the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weakness in abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination of the left arm suggests involvement of the C5-C6 nerve roots. The other options involve nerves that innervate different areas of the arm and hand.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weakness in abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination of the left arm suggest that the nerve damage is in the C5-C6 nerve roots, which innervate the deltoid and biceps brachii muscles. The absence of sensory changes and the hand being "bent backwards and facing the sky" suggests that it is not a radial nerve injury. The other options are not related to the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weakness and tenderness in the left shoulder region suggest a brachial plexus injury, specifically affecting the C5-C6 nerve roots. The other options, such as C8-T1 nerve roots, Radial nerve, and Long thoracic nerve, would not cause the described pattern of weakness and tenderness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest injury to the brachial plexus, specifically C5-C6 nerve roots, which innervate the muscles responsible for abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination of the arm. The radiograph being unremarkable suggests no bone fracture, and the lack of sensory changes suggests no nerve damage beyond the brachial plexus. Radial nerve innervates muscles responsible for wrist and finger extension and long thoracic nerve innervates serratus anterior muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a rotator cuff injury, and among the options, only C5-C6 nerve roots innervate the rotator cuff muscles. Radial nerve damage would cause weakness in extension of the arm and wrist, and Long thoracic nerve damage would cause winged scapula.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weakness in abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination of the left arm suggest injury to the C5-C6 nerve roots. The radial nerve is responsible for extension of the wrist and fingers, and the long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, which helps raise the arm above the head.
